climbs.name: Willis Tower - Get Your Stick and Lie Down.
climbs.fa: Mike Baker, Andy Roberts, Wilson Goodrich. May 2000

content.description: Start up a chimney-like crack, on softer, crumbly rock. After reaching a ledge, some good jams lead to a wider crack with stems to the top.
content.protection:
Cams to a #3 Camalot, medium and small pieces.

Anchor on top.
content.location: The hardest part for us was finding the tower. You can see the tower from Hwy. 191, up near the rim. We'd looked up at it several times, and decided to hike up to climb it. We wandered the length of Hidden Valley before finding it on the way back. Stay close to the valley's edge, overlooking Hwy. 191, until you look down on the tower.

content.description:
Not sure of the history or name of this one but thought I’d give it a name so it wasn’t just another “unknown tower”.  Let me know the real name and I’ll change it.

This route climbs up the west side via an obvious crack. Eventually the crack ends and you cut out right on face. Some gear can be placed in horizontals in this section.  Anchor on top is a sling boulder.  This surely goes all free at 5.10 or 5.10+.
content.protection:
Single set from .3-1

Double set from 2-4

Tat for the top
content.location: Start up the Hidden Valley trail. Just before the first meadow cut left on a trail that heads up the talus cone through the cliff bands and to the rim above. Once on top cut left(south) past ‘The Overlook’ until you reach the tower. At one point you have to go a bit west to avoid getting cliffed out.

content.description:
Not sure of the history or name of this one but thought I’d give it a name so it wasn’t just another “unknown tower”.  Let me know the real name and I’ll change it.

The route starts on the west side, scramble up ledges to a bulge with soft rock.  Mantle over the bulge to a dihedral which leads to a ledge on the north ridge. Pick your way around unstable rock following the ridge to the to summit. Anchor is two bolts.
content.protection:
Single set from .3-4

Tat for the anchor
content.location: Start up the Hidden Valley trail. Just before the first meadow cut left on a trail that heads up the talus cone through the cliff bands and to the rim above. Once on top cut left(south) along the rim  to the tower. At one point you have to go a bit west to avoid getting cliffed out.

content.description:
Not sure of the history or name of this one but thought I’d give it a name so it wasn’t just another “unknown tower”.  Let me know the real name and I’ll change it.

The route starts on the west side and climbs up to a ledge.  Place some small cams in horizontal cracks before climbing up and left on a rail. Mantle onto the rail and clip a bolt. Blowing this mantle would hurt. A few more moves and you’re on top.  THERE ARE NO SUMMIT ANCHORS!  You’ll have to do a simul rappel to get off.
content.location: The tower will be obvious above you on the left as you walk up the Hidden Valley trail. Access this little tower from the small valley SE of Hidden Valley. Just before entering the first meadow of Hidden Valley take the small trail that breaks left follow this up the hill staying left into the upper small valley.
